content:
This is probably a network issue more than a thunderbird issue. Copying messages from the online server to local folders requires a lot of interaction. Here is my suggestion to minimize interruptions: - install importexporttools NG addon - click file>offline>download to ensure all message content has downloaded - select the desired messages to move, righrclick and select the importexport option to export as eml - now, click Local Folders, rightclick and select the importexport option to import eml

That's a bit clunky, but it works.
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you for your reply. I will try that. I'm just curious what you mean by 'network issue'? I have blazing fast internet (download at +/-315 mbps and upload at 356 mbps). And even if I'm trying to move as few as 5 emails, TB drops one or two of them.
creator: queenmab100

content: By 'network issue', I am referring to the fact that you are competing with many others for the mail server and a fast internet connection still must cope with traffic. I won't pretend to have the skills to diagnose your connection; I speak only from my own experience.

content:
I am using Thunderbird ... version 142.0 (64-bit); McAfee LiveSafe version 1.32.165.1

McAfee has been problematic in connection with Thunderbird all the time. If I were you I'd get rid of it altogether, and just stick with Windows Defender.

If you want to keep McAfee, these are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. https://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile
creator: christ1

creator: Ansamb

content:
Alma Libre napsal(a)
u emailu hotmail to po mě neustále chce při stahování pošty heslo i přes zadání hesla a uložení do správce. Další problém nám s odesíláním z outlook emailu tam také vyžaduje heslo, když odesílám email po zadání a uložení hesla jen vyžaduje znovu.

AI mi našla toto: Tohle je častý problém při používání Thunderbirdu s účtem Hotmail/Outlook (Microsoft účty). Microsoft v posledních letech přestal podporovat klasické „heslo k účtu“ přes protokoly POP/IMAP/SMTP a vyžaduje moderní autentizaci (OAuth2) nebo tzv. App Password (aplikační heslo) pokud máte zapnuté dvoufázové ověřování. Proto se heslo pořád dokola ptá a neuloží se správně.

Jak to vyřešit: 1. Ověřte nastavení účtu v Thunderbirdu

Otevřete Nastavení účtů → Nastavení serveru:

IMAP server: outlook.office365.com, port 993, zabezpečení SSL/TLS

SMTP server: smtp.office365.com, port 587, zabezpečení STARTTLS

Metoda ověřování musí být nastavená na OAuth2 (ne heslo!).

Totéž zkontrolujte i pro odchozí poštu (SMTP).

2. Vymažte staré uložené heslo

Menu → Možnosti → Soukromí a zabezpečení → Uložená hesla

Najděte záznamy k outlook/hotmail a smažte je.

Po restartu Thunderbirdu vás to vyzve k přihlášení – tentokrát se otevře přihlašovací okno Microsoftu (webová stránka), kde zadáte e-mail a heslo.

3. Pokud máte zapnuté dvoufaktorové ověření (2FA)

Je potřeba vygenerovat si App Password na stránkách Microsoft účtu: Přihlásit se na https://account.live.com/proofs/manage

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)

content:
Thanks again. Maybe an update had reset the view.

I think there's scope to make some beneficial changes to the upper region. I get that hiding the menu bar saves space, although I'd rather that the search box and burger were gone and there was just the standard menu, which would actually reclaim more pixels. Search could be to the right of the menu bar, or it could be in the empty region at the very bottom of the main window. Alternatively, the search field could be hidden until shown with ctrl-K. Customising the mail view does allow the search box to be removed, but I couldn't find a way to get rid of the burger, so there's still dead space above the menu if search is removed. The burger could be made removable, or it could relocate to the right side of the menu bar when there's nothing else in the area above the menu bar.

content:
It depends. Your Thunderbird addressbook is inside the profile. If you have retained the profile from old PC, everything can be available. Do you have a backup? If the old PC is still available, these are the steps:

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there
creator: davidsk

content:
Check the Trash folder? Restore from your backup? It's easy to make a backup copy of your entire profile and you should do it regularly. I crafted a batch file that does it with one click. I'd be happy to share it.

If you use IMAP, the emails should still be on the server.

Not to say that it couldn't happen, but I've been using Thunderbird for decades and I've never had what you describe happen or heard of it happening to anybody anybody else.
creator: rednoise

content: [Delete]
creator: beskeptical

content: Any computer data that you can't do without needs to be backed up. Data corruption and loss can happen with any program on any computer. It's not a question of IF, it's a question of WHEN. Thunderbird is not immune, and whatever email solution you eventually choose won't be, either. Like I said, it's pretty simple to make a backup copy of your entire profile, which will preserve all your mail, configuration, addons, everything. That's one reason I stick with Thunderbird. Wherever you end up, back it up.
creator: rednoise

content:
Back up here and think.

The mail you are replying to is in your gmail account. Of course Thunderbird is going to use it to try and reply. If you have a look at your replies, you may even notice a change in the from to your gmail account.

If you do not want this happening you need to use an identity. One specific for the Outlook account. To do this you need to have an entry in the outgoing server (SMTP) part of your setting to use the outgoing outlook SMTP server along with any specific

Then you need to go into the identity part of your gmail account (the first pane where you name and email address is) and click the manage identities button. add an identity for your outlook email that is on the gmail account and select the outlook SMTP server to use when sending mail.

As Thunderbird acts as a mail aggregator for multiple accounts, I suggest you seriously think about why you are forwarding all mail from one account to another. Thunderbird on android will work just as well as Thunderbird on your desktop so why put yourself in this situation in the first place? I have been seeing folks doing it for most of the last 20 years. I still do not understand the why. So apologies in advance if I appear obtuse. I genuinely do not understand why folk, do this.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
For the old account:

  1. install importexporttools NG addon
  2. highlight inbox of old account
  3. rightclick and select importexport option to export mbox
  4. highlight Local Folders
  5. rightclick and select the importexport option to import mbox
  6. repeat for other folders in account
  7. once you have checked to see all messages now saved in Local Folders, you can delete the old account.

For the gmail account, post screenshot of the error message and any other info you may feel appropriate. Be sure that you have thunderbird set to accept cookies (settings>privacy&security) and DO NOT enter password during setup but wait for Google to ask for it
